Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2010 06:18PM Paula1231 wrote: Mindy this is what I found: The Nottingham histologic score is simply a scoring system to assess the "grade" of breast cancers. It is a total score based on 3 different sub-scores. The 3 sub-scores are assigned based on 3 components of how the breast cancer cells look under a microscope. (The details of these 3 components are not critical for you to understand). Each of the 3 components is assigned a sub-score of 1, 2, or 3, with 1 being best and 3 being worst. Once the 3 sub-scores are added, a Nottingham score is obtained: the minimum score possible is 3 (1+1+1) and the maximum possible is 9 (3+3+3). A histologic grade of III is assigned to any patient with a Nottingham score of 8 or 9. Grade I refers to Nottingham scores of 3, 4, and 5, while Grade II refers to Nottingham scores of 6 and 7. In the end, the Nottingham score and histologic grades are not very useful in the big picture, as they do not alter final overall treatment recommendations. High-score cancers tend to relapse more often than low-score cancers. Ultimately, however, we don't use the score in making clinical decisions.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 09:55AM Paula1231 wrote: Please, don't quit!  I know how you feel, I had DD AC and DD Taxol and just finished last week.  On my third AC I wanted to crawl into a dark closet and just close the door. As the time for the last AC drew nearer, I would cry in the bathroom stall at work.  I wanted to quit and so badly, but, I showed up with an ativan for courage and slept thru the last AC chemo.  Even tho I had non stop diarrea and ached everywhere, It only lasted six horrible days.  Then I was on the mend.  The taxol was not nearly as bad as the AC, altho my bones hurt terribly on day three - six.  Now that I am done, my body is slowly healing and I am feeling like I will live and actually enjoy life.  Hang in there, and what ever you do, I send prayers and huggs your way.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 09:12PM Paula1231 wrote: Hi LoriAnn. Here is the skinny on TRICARE: TRICARE Moves BRCA Testing to No Government Pay Procedure Code List TRICARE Management Activity (TMA) has determined that they will not allow payment for BRCA testing. The BRCA gene test is a blood test that uses DNA analysis to identify harmful changes (mutations) in either one of the two breast cancer susceptibility genes - BRCA1 and BRCA2. As a result of this directive, TMA added all BRCA lab test codes to the No Government Pay Procedure Code List effective January 1, 2012. Previously, TriWest Healthcare Alliance (TriWest) paid the BRCA codes without prior authorization. With this change, TriWest must deny all claims submitted for this procedure with dates of service January 1, 2012 or later. The existing Healthcare Common procedure Coding System (HCPCS) codes below were added to the No Government Pay Procedure Code List, effective January 1, 2012: The new Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) codes below were also added: For more information, refer to the TRICARE Policy Manual, Chapter 7, Sections 2.1 & 2.2, at http://cl.exct.net/?qs=25ef06f050ffb85af7748d8784d6c4c3c528bee767eb0f1f2c9e4705db14a204.

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 11:26PM Paula1231 wrote: Just had one this morning.  The radiologist used a needle to inject lidocaine to numb the area.  This was a small prick and did not hurt much.  Felt weird, I could feel the lidocaine move toward my underarm.  He used the ultrasound to locate the mass.  I was posittioned very comfortabley so the lump could be biopsied without injury to my implant or lung.  The Radiologist used a scapel to cut a small opening in the skin and while using the ultrasound guided the needle gun close to the tumor.  He counted 1,2,3 and the little gun discharged the needle.  It did not hurt at all.  Just a bit of pressure.  He repeated three times and shot the biopsy into a small container of formalin which I checked carefully for my name to make sure it was labeled correctly.  Now I need to wait about 4-6 days for results. Compared to the wait for results, the core biopsy was a breeze.  My DH held my hand and sent waves of comfort.  Thank God for my DH.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 02:04PM Paula1231 wrote: Hello Marial, I had a blip on my thyroid and lung also.  The thyroid biopsy was negative.  I did not let them puncture my lung, however the nodule has not increased in size.  My onc says 80 percent of all people have thyroid nodules and they are B9.  Blips in the lungs are very common too especially in really dry or wet areas.  Most turn out to be B9 also.  Hang in there and let me know how everything goes for you.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 04:42PM Paula1231 wrote: I agree with CoolBreeze..On the initial scan, they found thyroid nodules and a lung nodule.  I even had a suspicious spot on my rib.  They put a needle in my thyroid and it was B9.  I drew the line at the lung puncture, and at puncturing my rib bone, but my Onc said the radiologist said the lung did not look really suspicious and that almost everyone has nodules especially in dry climates.   Six months post chemo, I had a rib/back pain and a panic attack.  My onc ordered more scans and nothing had grown or "lit up".  I think I am just paranoid.  But it was nice to know for sure.

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 12:56PM Paula1231 wrote: I had a left breast MX with TE on August 17.  I was approved as an inpatient for two days but went home on the 18th in the late afternoon.  It was my BS and not my PS who asked for auth.  I have BC/BS and they had no issue with the auth for a two day stay.  Maybe try contacting your surgeon?  I work for a health plan and they can get an auth in hours.  I was not in very much pain.  No party, I assure you, but my BS/Anesthesia team did a nerve "block" so I came out of sugery feeling pretty good.  I had IV pain meds and antibiotics the whole time till I left and converted to the Oxy once I got home.  I am almost 4 weeks post op and while I am a bit achy, I do not have major pain and take advil towards the end of day. Good luck with your surgery and I am wishing fast healing for you as well.
